questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • B) Ego-dystonic – True This means the thoughts are experienced as alien or inconsistent with the person’s self-concept or values, and the individual recognizes them as irrational or senseless but is unable to control them.
  • • C) Persists on resistance and causes depression and anxiety – True Despite attempts to resist or suppress the obsessions, they persist, often leading to intense distress, anxiety, or secondary depression. The more the person tries to stop them, the more distressing they become.
  • • D) Disorder of content of thought – True Obsessions fall under disorders of the content of thought, as they involve abnormal, repetitive intrusive ideas or themes, unlike disorders of the form of thought (like loosening of associations in schizophrenia).
  • • A) May be seen in schizophrenia – False / Exception While obsession-like symptoms may occasionally occur in schizophrenia, true obsessions, as seen in OCD, are rare in schizophrenia. In schizophrenia, intrusive thoughts are often ego-syntonic (accepted as part of the self), bizarre, or associated with delusions or hallucinations, rather than the classic ego-dystonic and anxiety-inducing obsessions of OCD.
  • • Final Answer: A) May be seen in schizophrenia – This is the exception and therefore the correct choice.

questions.text: A 30 – years old pregnant woman comes to your clinic with decreased sleep, increased appetite and hyperactivity for 2 weeks. A diagnosis of mania is made. Further probing reveals four episodes of major depression in the past two years. What drug will you prescribe to the patients?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why Haloperidol is correct: Haloperidol is a typical antipsychotic that is commonly used for acute management of mania, especially in pregnant patients, due to a more established safety profile in pregnancy compared to mood stabilizers.
  • • It does not carry the teratogenic risks associated with some other agents (e.g., lithium or valproate).
  • • It is effective in rapidly controlling agitation and psychotic symptoms.
  • • Incorrect Options: B) Lithium – Although lithium is effective for bipolar disorder and prevention of manic and depressive episodes, it is not recommended in the first trimester due to its association with Ebstein's anomaly (a rare cardiac defect). It may be used cautiously later in pregnancy under strict monitoring, but not first-line in acute mania during early pregnancy.
  • • C) Promethazine – This is an antihistamine with sedative properties, not an antipsychotic or mood stabilizer. It is not effective for treating mania.
  • • D) Clonazepam – A benzodiazepine, which may help with short-term agitation or sleep, but it is not a treatment for mania and carries risks in pregnancy, including potential neonatal withdrawal and floppy infant syndrome.

questions.text: A 23 – year –old young boy with schizophrenia is well maintained on risperidone for the last 2 months. He has no family history of the disease. Minimum for how long will you continue treatment in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • This 23-year-old patient has:
  • • A first episode of schizophrenia
  • • Been stable on risperidone for 2 months
  • • No family history (suggesting a possibly lower long-term risk)
  • • The minimum recommended duration of maintenance therapy after a first episode of schizophrenia is 12 months (1 year), as per major guidelines including APA and NICE.
  • • Why 12 months is correct: Even after remission, the risk of relapse remains high, particularly in the first year.
  • • Antipsychotic discontinuation earlier than 12 months is associated with significantly increased relapse rates.
  • • Long-term outcomes are better when treatment is continued for at least 1 year after remission.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A) 5 years – Too long as a minimum duration for a first episode without family history. Extended treatment may be needed in recurrent or high-risk patients, but not typically after a single episode.
  • • B) 6 months – Insufficient. Studies show that relapse rates are higher when antipsychotics are discontinued before 12 months after the first episode.
  • • C) 2 years – May be appropriate in patients with high risk of relapse, multiple episodes, or poor insight. However, it's not the minimum duration for all patients.

questions.text: A young female on antidepressants presents to the emergency with altered sensorium and hypotension . ECG reveals wide ORS complexes and right axis deviation. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • History of antidepressant use
  • • Altered sensorium and hypotension
  • • ECG findings:
  • • Wide QRS complexes (>100 ms is dangerous)
  • • Right axis deviation
  • • These are classic signs of TCA toxicity (e.g., amitriptyline, imipramine), which cause:
  • • Cardiac sodium channel blockade
  • • Leading to conduction delays → wide QRS
  • • Hypotension due to alpha-1 adrenergic blockade and myocardial depression
  • • CNS toxicity (e.g., delirium, seizures, coma)
  • • Why Sodium Bicarbonate is the correct answer: Sodium bicarbonate is the first-line antidote for TCA-induced cardiotoxicity.
  • • It:
  • • Alkalinizes the serum → reduces binding of TCAs to sodium channels
  • • Provides sodium → directly combats sodium channel blockade
  • • It helps narrow the QRS, improve blood pressure, and stabilize cardiac membranes.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B) Hemodialysis – Ineffective in TCA overdose because TCAs are highly protein-bound and lipophilic, making them poorly dialyzable.
  • • C) Fomepizole – Used for methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning, not antidepressant overdose.
  • • D) Flumazenil – Benzodiazepine antidote. Not only ineffective in TCA overdose, but it may worsen seizures in mixed overdoses.
  • • Conclusion: The next best step in this case of suspected TCA overdose is Sodium bicarbonate, making Option A the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is a key symptom in alcohol withdrawal?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why Tremors are the key symptom: Tremors are among the earliest and most common withdrawal signs.
  • • They typically involve fine, rapid shaking of the hands ("the shakes").
  • • Tremors can be accompanied by other autonomic symptoms such as sweating, anxiety, and palpitations.
  • • Why the other options are less typical or later symptoms: A) Visual hallucinations
  • • Can occur but are less common and usually part of alcohol withdrawal hallucinosis, which is separate from delirium tremens.
  • • B) Sleep disturbance
  • • Common in alcohol withdrawal but nonspecific and less characteristic than tremors.
  • • D) Delirium (Delirium Tremens)
  • • A severe and life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal, but occurs later (48-72 hours after last drink), not a key early symptom.
  • • Conclusion: Tremors are the hallmark and key early symptom of alcohol withdrawal, making Option C the correct answer.

questions.text: A person with histrionic shy, anxious avoidant personality comes under which cluster
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Cluster A: Odd or eccentric disorders (e.g., Paranoid, Schizoid, Schizotypal)
  • • Cluster B: Dramatic, emotional, or erratic disorders (e.g., Antisocial, Borderline, Histrionic, Narcissistic)
  • • Cluster C: Anxious or fearful disorders (e.g., Avoidant, Dependent, Obsessive-Compulsive)
  • • Why Cluster C is correct here: The person has histrionic, shy, and anxious avoidant traits.
  • • Although Histrionic is usually a Cluster B personality disorder, shy and anxious avoidant traits point towards Cluster C, which includes Avoidant personality disorder and others characterized by anxiety and fearfulness.
  • • Since the question groups these traits together, and the focus is on shy, anxious, avoidant features, the correct cluster is C.
  • • Summary: Cluster C includes Avoidant personality disorder and other anxious/fearful types.
  • • The traits described align best with Cluster C disorders.

questions.text: Feeling of uncertainity and excessive sense of responsibility seen in
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Patients with OCD often experience doubt and uncertainty about their actions (e.g., "Did I lock the door?"), leading to repeated checking behaviors.
  • • The excessive sense of responsibility drives compulsions, as patients believe their actions (or inactions) could cause harm or negative outcomes.
  • • Why other options are less accurate: A) Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)
  • • Characterized by excessive worry about multiple life events but not specifically uncertainty or responsibility related to compulsions.
  • • C) Phobia
  • • Involves irrational fear of specific objects or situations, not a pervasive sense of responsibility or uncertainty.
  • • D) Personality Disorder
  • • Personality disorders may involve maladaptive traits but do not typically present with excessive uncertainty or compulsive responsibility.
  • • Conclusion: The uncertainty and excessive responsibility described point strongly towards OCD.

questions.text: A woman comes to the psychiatrist with history of spending a lot of time in washing her hands . She is distressed about it but sayss that she cannot stop the practice and spends a lot of time on it. This has started affecting her social life as well. Which is the best treatment?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is the best treatment: ERP is a specific type of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) focused on gradually exposing patients to feared situations (e.g., germs) without allowing them to perform compulsive behaviors (e.g., washing hands).
  • • This therapy helps patients tolerate anxiety and learn that feared outcomes do not happen, thereby reducing compulsions.
  • • It has been shown to be highly effective and first-line psychological treatment for OCD.
  • • Why the other options are less ideal or incomplete: A) Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
  • • CBT is broad; ERP is a specialized, evidence-based form of CBT specifically for OCD. So ERP is more precise.
  • • C) Systematic Desensitization
  • • Used mainly for phobias by gradual exposure combined with relaxation, less effective for OCD compulsions.
  • • D) Pharmacological agents
  • • Useful adjuncts, especially SSRIs, but behavioral therapy (ERP) is considered first-line or combined approach.
  • • Conclusion: For OCD with compulsive hand-washing, Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is the most effective, evidence-based psychological treatment.

questions.text: All are features of catatonia except :
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why Akathisia is not a feature of catatonia: Akathisia is a movement disorder marked by inner restlessness and an inability to stay still, typically a side effect of antipsychotic medications (especially first-generation ones).
  • • It is not considered a core feature of catatonia and represents a distinct clinical condition.
  • • Features commonly seen in catatonia (and why options B–D are correct): B) Ambitendency –
  • • Refers to inability to complete a voluntary action due to opposing movements (e.g., reaching out to shake hands, then withdrawing).
  • • Seen in catatonia as a form of psychomotor disturbance.
  • • C) Akinesia –
  • • A marked decrease in motor activity, can present as stupor or immobility, typical of catatonic patients.
  • • D) Agitation –
  • • Catatonia has both hypoactive and hyperactive forms.
  • • In the excited type, agitation and excessive motor activity are prominent.
  • • Conclusion: While catatonia includes symptoms like ambitendency, akinesia, and even agitation, akathisia is a drug-induced movement disorder, not a feature of catatonia.

questions.text: A smoker Is worried about the side effects of smoking. But he does not stop smoking thinking that he smokes less as compared to other and takes a good diet . This thinking is callsed as
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why Self-exemption is the correct term: Self-exemption is a cognitive distortion where a person believes that general risks or rules don’t apply to them personally.
  • • It allows individuals to reduce cognitive dissonance—the discomfort that arises from holding two conflicting beliefs (e.g., “Smoking is harmful” vs. “I continue to smoke”).
  • • Instead of changing the behavior (smoking), the person modifies their belief to justify the action.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B) Cognitive behavior
  • • A broad term encompassing thoughts influencing behavior; not specific to the justification mechanism described.
  • • C) Self-protection
  • • Involves strategies to defend self-esteem or avoid psychological harm, but not specifically about denying personal risk.
  • • D) Distortion
  • • Too general; "cognitive distortion" is a broader umbrella under which self-exemption falls.

questions.text: Patient us suffering from schizophrenia and is on antipsychotics. Which of the following is not correctly matched with respect to mechanism of action of antipsychotics?

options.label: A
options.text: Blockage of D2 receptors in mesolimbic pathway helps in control of positive symptoms

options.label: B
options.text: 5HT2a blockage helps in control of negative symptoms

options.label: C
options.text: 5HT1a blockage helps in reducing positive symptoms and causes weight loss

options.label: D
options.text: Anti cholinergic (M1 blockage) action helps to reduce extrapyramidal side effects

questions.correct_answer: C. 5HT1a blockage helps in reducing positive symptoms and causes weight loss
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In fact, agonism (not blockage) at 5HT1a is sometimes associated with anxiolytic and antidepressant effects.
  • • Additionally, 5HT1a blockade is not associated with weight loss — weight gain is more commonly linked to 5HT2c and H1 histamine receptor antagonism.
  • • Thus, option C is incorrectly matched.
  • • Explanation of Incorrect Options: A) Blockage of D2 receptors in mesolimbic pathway helps in control of positive symptoms
  • • Correct. This is the primary mechanism by which typical and atypical antipsychotics reduce hallucinations and delusions (positive symptoms).
  • • B) 5HT2a blockage helps in control of negative symptoms
  • • Correct. Atypical antipsychotics (like risperidone, olanzapine) block 5HT2a receptors, which modulates dopamine release in various brain regions and may improve negative symptoms.
  • • D) Anticholinergic (M1 blockage) action helps to reduce extrapyramidal side effects
  • • Correct. M1 receptor antagonism can reduce EPS (e.g., parkinsonism, dystonia) by restoring dopamine-acetylcholine balance in the nigrostriatal pathway.

questions.correct_answer: A. Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why Option A is true: Korsakoff’s syndrome is characterized primarily by anterograde amnesia, meaning the patient cannot form new memories (loss of recent memory).
  • • Patients have difficulty learning and retaining new information, while remote memories might be relatively preserved.
  • • This leads to severe memory impairment especially for recent events.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B) Triad of acute confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia
  • • This describes Wernicke’s encephalopathy, the acute precursor to Korsakoff’s syndrome, not Korsakoff’s itself.
  • • C) Loss of identity memory and intact personality
  • • Korsakoff’s patients typically have memory deficits, but loss of identity memory (autobiographical memory) can be variable, and personality may be affected.
  • • D) Impairment of implicit memory and immediate recall
  • • Korsakoff’s syndrome mainly affects explicit (declarative) memory, particularly anterograde memory.
  • • Implicit memory and immediate recall are relatively spared.

questions.text: A Patient with severe depression was treated with TCA and reported significant improvement of symptoms after 4 weeks. Which of the following is most important concern, at the time of his discharge?

  • • Why other options are less critical at discharge: A) Modafinil to counter the sedative effect

questions.text: Consider the correct statements 1-Contemplation - A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking but not sure 2 - Precontemplation - A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health 3- Maintenance phase- A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then 4- Action phase- A person with obesity says he cant do anything as it runs deep in his family

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in beck’s cognitive theory of depression?

  • • C. Cognitive distortions: Systematic errors in thinking (e.g., overgeneralization, catastrophizing).
  • • D. Dysfunctional beliefs: Deeply held negative beliefs about oneself and the world, formed early in life and activated in stressful situations.
  • • B. Introjection, on the other hand, is a psychoanalytic concept (originating from Freud), referring to the unconscious adoption of the ideas or attitudes of others (e.g., internalizing the voice of a critical parent). It is not a component of Beck’s cognitive theory.

questions.correct_answer: A. Fine tremors are seen at therapeutic blood levels
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Fine tremors are seen at therapeutic blood levels — True Fine hand tremors are a common and well-documented side effect of lithium even at therapeutic levels (0.6–1.2 mEq/L).
  • • These tremors are typically benign but may be distressing to patients.
  • • Propranolol is often used to treat lithium-induced tremors.
  • • B. Lithium is not absorbed from the gut — False Incorrect. Lithium is well absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract.
  • • It reaches peak plasma levels within 1–2 hours of oral administration.
  • • C. It doesn’t cause teratogenicity — False Incorrect. Lithium is teratogenic, particularly associated with Ebstein's anomaly, a rare congenital heart defect, when used during the first trimester of pregnancy.
  • • D. Approved drug for use in absence seizures — False Incorrect. Lithium is not used and not approved for absence seizures.
  • • In fact, lithium may lower the seizure threshold in some individuals.

questions.text: Mr X has low mood since past few months decreased personal hygiene, loss of appetite and low energy levels. On Mental status examination his thoughts were: I'm dead i don't have a head how will I eat? Which delusion?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • What are Nihilistic Delusions? These are false beliefs involving nonexistence of self, body parts, or the external world.
  • • Most commonly seen in severe depression, especially psychotic depression.
  • • Often associated with Cotard's syndrome, a rare condition characterized by nihilistic delusions.
  • • Option Clarification: A. Paranoid – Involves beliefs of being persecuted or conspired against.
  • • C. Bizarre – Delusions that are clearly implausible (e.g., "my thoughts are being beamed into outer space"). While nihilistic delusions are strange, they are not necessarily categorized as bizarre in the technical psychiatric sense.
  • • D. Cotard – This is not a type of delusion, but a syndrome in which nihilistic delusions are the core symptom. So while Cotard's syndrome may describe the clinical picture, the specific type of delusion is nihilistic.

questions.text: Which of the following is included in criterion of substance dependence? A. The substance is often taken in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended B. The substance use is continued despite having a physical problem that is likely to have been caused by the substance C. Tolerance D. important social, occupational, or recreational activities are given up or reduced because of substance use
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Larger amounts or longer duration than intended The person consumes more of the substance or for a longer time than they planned.
  • • B. Continued use despite physical/psychological harm The person keeps using the substance even when they are aware it is causing or worsening a health problem.
  • • C. Tolerance Increasing doses of the substance are needed to achieve the same effect, or the same amount produces a diminished effect.
  • • D. Neglect of important activities Social, occupational, or recreational activities are reduced or abandoned because of substance use.
  • • Additional Common Criteria Include: Withdrawal symptoms when stopping the substance.
  • • Persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control use.
  • • A great deal of time is spent in obtaining, using, or recovering from the substance.
